turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Which it did here.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: The principle of law, if you're looking to common law the principle is that you'd have no expectation that anybody... if it's placed in a shared and common location, where the custom is that other people handle it, then you would have no cause of action if somebody else handled it, and you'd have no--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Would you have a cause of action if someone touches your chattel and thereby causes harm to you, if someone trespasses on your chattel and causes harm to you, which is what happened here?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --I... Justice Kennedy, I can't fathom what the nature of the harm is.
I think they'd have to injure the chattel and deprive you of possession of--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I think your opposing counsel will say that the owner is in jail as a result of the touching.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --Yes, but I'm not sure that that... certainly that would give you standing to seek suppression of the evidence, but that would not be sufficient for purposes of a tort action.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I don't think it's regarded as common law harm.
It--

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: Pardon?
No, it wouldn't be regarded as a common law harm.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --It's called justice, really, in common law, isn't it?
Well, if a fellow passenger got up and jarred Bond's bag, such that the brick fell out, I don't think the fellow passenger would be liable for damages for his imprisonment.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: No, I don't think that would--
[Laughter]
He certainly would not, and I think that's a very good analogy.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But that was not intentional.
This is an intentional tort, and that's the difference.
There's a difference between intentional and unintentional torts.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So if the fellow passenger intentionally threw it the ground and the brick fell out, the fellow passenger would be liable for his imprisonment?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: Again, I think a--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The fellow passenger is not an agent of the State, so it would take away the--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Let's let counsel--

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --Exactly, since he's not an agent of the State.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But you were about to make a distinction between the cloakroom, and that seems to me the same thing.
You hang up your coat in a public space, so why couldn't the police go into every coatroom and start manipulating what's there?

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: The coatrooms that I've seen, Your Honor, there would be no reason for anybody else ever to have contact with your possessions, with your coats, and certainly not the pockets.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, there are plenty of coatrooms where there is no attendant.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You just put your coat there.
You may put your bag, hard or soft--

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --Right.
If it begins to resemble and have the characteristics of the overhead rack, then we would agree that you don't have a reasonable expectation of privacy.
If I could turn to the record for one moment, I'd like to point out one thing.

Whether or not the object was disguised in the various ways that petitioner declares would not make much of a difference to the agent feeling the package, since what they're attuned to are things that are signature disguises.
But the record also does not reflect that this was a rectangular object that was then so wrapped in duct tape that it somehow became rounded.
At page 23 of the transcript, the agent describes it as a brick with rounded edges, and it was a brick with rounded edges, so it could also be described as an oval mass.
In fact, petitioner's own brief in the district court described the object as an oval brick.
It's for that reason I don't think it's fair to construe the record as having an object that had sharp edges and was so wrapped up in brick... in tape--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --There isn't any 23, or at least the appendix--

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --Joint appendix?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --The joint appendix doesn't seem to go... the transcript doesn't seem to go beyond page 20.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: 26, I think... oh, if you're talking about--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The--

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: --It's... joint appendix, page 26, is the district court opinion quoting petitioner's description of it as an oval brick; in the transcript pages, page 53, which does not appear in the joint appendix.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Thanks.

turn.speaker: jeffrey_a_lamken
turn.label: Mr. Jeffrey A. Lamken
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Lamken.
Ms. Fuentes, you have 4 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: m_carolyn_fuentes
turn.label: Ms. M. Carolyn Fuentes
turn.text: I think overall, Your Honor, the... all of the Government's argument is based on the knowing exposure of Mr. Bond's bag, and those cases that this Court has decided on knowing exposure vary so radically from Mr. Bond's situation that they should not be applied.

That public exposure principle has been applied primarily for visual observations with very limited exceptions, the garbage case, for example, and luggage is different than garbage, and I believe Maryland v. Macon, where police officers went into a store where people were invited to buy, and they bought.
So they touched it, they bought, they did just what the public could do.
But on that line, what happened to Mr. Bond was much closer to Dickerson and to Terry, and so the public exposure principle should not be applied.

Instead, the limited public access principles in Mancuson v. DeForte, for example, just because other people have access to our office doesn't mean that the police can have access, those principles, as well as Dickerson and Terry, are more applicable in this case.
I also wanted to say one thing about purpose, and that is that purpose can be instructive if it is manifested by objective actions, and that purpose is what helps to define reasonable expectations.
We do expect that other passengers may move our luggage for the purpose of making room for their own, and when their actions go beyond that, our reasonable expectations of privacy are violated.

More than 30 years ago, in Terry, this Court had to decide whether it wanted to isolate an entire range of police conduct from Fourth Amendment constraints, and really much the same question is before the Court today.
Will the police be permitted to manipulate luggage basically as much as they want under the Government's theory?
If anything could have been observed by a member of the public, then the police are entitled to observe it.
Will they be able to do that outside the constraints of the Fourth Amendment, and I think the answer should be no.
Unless the court has any more questions--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, I'll ask you one... I mean, when I came into this, I thought, well, it isn't that hard.

Maybe it is harder, but the real question's just whether, when you put this luggage up in a place, you have a reasonable expectation that somebody could go and feel the brick, and if the answer's yes, then he has no expectation.
The answer's no, he does.
All right, now, on that theory the only way... the answer must be yes, there's a good chance somebody would feel the brick unless it requires a special hard touch, all right?

turn.speaker: m_carolyn_fuentes
turn.label: Ms. M. Carolyn Fuentes
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now what?
I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: m_carolyn_fuentes
turn.label: Ms. M. Carolyn Fuentes
turn.text: Well, I think the answer is, the reason they will do it is to move their luggage, and your expectations would be violated if it were an empty bus and someone came and started touching your luggage anyway, and when our reasonable expectations of privacy are violated by private persons, that doesn't matter for Fourth Amendment purposes.

But when the Government does it, and Agent Cantu did it in this case, that is covered by the Fourth Amendment, and unless it is done with some sort of individualized suspicion, it is a violation of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Fuentes.
The case is submitted.
